In general, Brett recommends removing contigs less than 4000 bp from your bins. For bins based largely on tetranucleotide frequency, this matters a lot because short contigs are not long enough for reliable TNF results. But my bins were made in large part based on coverage across samples (metabat2 weighs this more the more samples you include). However, the ends of contigs are less reliable and short contigs have a larger proportion of end regions, so their coverage values could also be less reliable. To decide whether to go back and remove short contigs, I looked at the bins in 2 ways. First, I looked at how much short contigs actually contributed to the total bin size. Second, I looked at how average bin coverage changed when excluding the ends of contigs. 

## Contribution of short contigs

I wanted to know, did the short contigs even get binned? And if so, how much did they contribute to the bins? To look at this, I used the script `scripts/2022-11-16_are_there_short_contigs_in_the_bins.R` to explore the contribution of short contigs to a bin. I calculated contribution by looking at the total base pairs (not the total scaffolds) contributed by short scaffolds vs. the total base pairs in the bin.  

For this analysis I looked at just the bins from a single sample, because that was manageable to download to my computer. I could repeat it later with just the drep winners, but some drep winners are also included in the example sample I used.

## Coverage of contig ends

CoverM lets you calculate coverage excluding coverage at the ends of the contigs, so I ran this calculation with different lengths of contigs excluded. The idea was that I would see coverage "level off" once the noisy unreliable contig end was removed. For this I used "mean coverage" instead of relative abundance.  

I did this using coverM results from running on the 95% ANI bins (I mapped to 95% ANI winners and ran coverM and a TIMEOUT partial inStrain run before switching to 96% ANI winners). 

To run a range of coverMs, I generated scripts with `server-scripts/written/2023-02-01_run_coverM/2023-02-05_make_coverM_submit_scripts.R`.  I ran coverM once per node, with 42 threads because it was memory-limited. It took 5 1/2 hours.

```{bash, eval=F}
#!/bin/bash
#SBATCH -J coverm
#SBATCH -p normal
#SBATCH -N 5
#SBATCH -n 15
#SBATCH -t 30:0:00
#SBATCH -o coverm.o%j
#SBATCH -e coverm.e%j
#SBATCH --mail-type=all
#SBATCH --mail-user=rohwer@utexas.edu
module load launcher
export LAUNCHER_JOB_FILE=get_coverm_means.launcher
export LAUNCHER_SCHED=interleaved
${LAUNCHER_DIR}/paramrun
```

##### Contig end-exclusion results:

I processed the coverM end-exclusion comparison results using `scripts/2023-02-06_look_at_coverM_ends_cutoff.R`.  

Some bins had higher coverage at the contig ends, so coverage decreased when ends were excluded.

![](../figures/figures/2023-02-01_coverM_end_cutoff_comparisons_perc/p__Actinobacteriota\ c__Acidimicrobiia\ o__Acidimicrobiales\ f__Ilumatobacteraceae\ g__UBA3006\ s__\ ME2000-10-10pf_3300042337_group1_bin21\ .png){}

Other bins had lower coverage at the ends, so coverage increased when ends were excluded.

![](../figures/2023-02-01_coverM_end_cutoff_comparisons_perc/p__Proteobacteria\ c__Alphaproteobacteria\ o__Sphingomonadales\ f__Sphingomonadaceae\ g__Erythrobacter\ s__\ ME2015-06-19_3300044640_group6_bin157\ .png){}

Others looked like old wooden ships up on supports for land maintenance (a mix of both).

![](../figures/2023-02-01_coverM_end_cutoff_comparisons_perc/p__Proteobacteria\ c__Alphaproteobacteria\ o__Rhizobiales\ f__Aestuariivirgaceae\ g__Aestuariivirga\ s__\ ME2001-07-02D8pf_3300042397_group1_bin88\ .png){}

But when I put all bins on top of each other, it shows higher variability at the ends and a then a slower decrease in coverage.

![](../figures/2023-02-01_coverM_end_cutoff_comparisons_absolute/1-summary_overall_mean.png){width=60%}

![](../figures/2023-02-01_coverM_end_cutoff_comparisons_perc/1-summary_overall_mean-perc.png){width=60%}


Based on this, we decided to calculate bin coverage after passing the "hump" in the combined plot. We thought this meant the funky edge effects have passed by then. So we will run coverM using `--contig-end-exclusion 1000`. And we will also be skeptical downstream of results that are within 1000 bp of the end of a contig.

_Note that all of these calculations were done with bins de-replicated to 95% ANI, while the representative genomes I decided to use in downstream analyses were the 96% ANI bins.

## Including short contigs

The shortest contigs included by bbmap and metabat2 in creating the bins are 2,500 bp.  
Short contigs constitute a large portion of some bins, even the very low contamination ones, and including organisms of particular interest that don't assemble well (acI-B).  
CoverM results suggest that contig coverage is sketchy withing 1000 bp of the ends.  
We decided to still include the short contigs, but to have skepticism if important results are found on short contigs (which could have skewed coverage results leading to erroneous inclusion in the bins), and especially to be skeptical of results that fall near contig ends for contigs of any length.  
In future, short contigs of particular interest could be examined to see if mid-contig coverage matches that of the bin over time well.
